name: OS and Networks
timeline: 1956: GM-NAA I/O, considered the first operating system, is developed.
1961: CTSS (Compatible Time-Sharing System) is developed at MIT, pioneering time-sharing concepts.
1969: ARPANET, a precursor to the Internet, is established; UNIX operating system is created at Bell Labs.
1971: UNIX operating system design prioritizes simplicity and portability, influencing future OSes.
1974: TCP/IP protocols are defined, laying the groundwork for modern internet communication.
1983: ARPANET fully adopts TCP/IP, marking the official birth of the Internet.
1984: Apple Macintosh popularizes Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs), changing user interaction with OSes.
1991: Linus Torvalds releases the Linux kernel, leading to the open-source Linux ecosystem.
2000s: Virtualization technologies (e.g., VMware, Xen) become mainstream for server consolidation.
2007: Apple releases iOS, revolutionizing mobile operating systems.
2013-2015: Containerization (Docker) and Software-Defined Networking (SDN) emerge as key technologies.
2020s: AI-enhanced operating systems and networking, quantum and edge networking gain prominence.

subfields.name: Operating Systems
timeline: 1956: GM-NAA I/O is developed, marking the first operating system.
1961: CTSS (Compatible Time-Sharing System) pioneers time-sharing on computers.
1969: UNIX is created at Bell Labs, influencing modern OS design with its modularity.
1971: The concept of UNIX portability is established, allowing it to run on different hardware.
1984: Apple Macintosh introduces a commercially successful Graphical User Interface (GUI).
1991: The Linux kernel is released, leading to the development of numerous Linux distributions.
2000s: Virtualization technologies become widespread for server consolidation and cloud computing.
2013-2015: Container technologies like Docker gain prominence for lightweight application isolation.
2020s: AI integration into OS for predictive scheduling, anomaly detection, and enhanced security.
advancements: AI-Powered System Optimization and Adaptive Resource Management.
Cloud-Native and Hybrid OS Platforms for seamless multi-device access.
Enhanced Security with Zero-Trust Models and advanced encryption.
Real-time OS advancements for safety-critical robotic perception.
Containerization and Orchestration (Docker, Kubernetes) for application deployment.
Unikernels for resource-constrained embedded systems.
Improved I/O Efficiency and I/O scheduling algorithms.

subfields.name: Computer Networks
keyProblems: Scalability and Capacity Concerns in large networks
applications: Voice over IP (VoIP) and Video Conferencing
timeline: 1969: ARPANET, the first operational packet switching network, is established.
1973: Ethernet, a key local area networking technology, is developed by Robert Metcalfe.
1974: The TCP/IP protocol suite is formally defined, becoming the foundation of the Internet.
1983: ARPANET transitions to TCP/IP, leading to the rapid growth of interconnected networks.
1990s: The World Wide Web (WWW) is launched, making information widely accessible over the Internet.
1997: Wi-Fi (IEEE 802.11 standard) is introduced, enabling wireless local area networks.
2013-2015: Software-Defined Networking (SDN) and Network Function Virtualization (NFV) gain traction.
2020s: AI-enhanced networking and the development of 5G/6G technologies reshape network capabilities.
